titleStmt.title: The honourable actions of that most famous and valiant Englishman, Edward Glemham, Esquire Lately obtained against the Spaniards, and the holy Leauge [sic], in foure sundry fightes. With his landing on S. Georges Ile, belonging to our enemie, which he kept with foure score and six men, the space of 48. houres. With his like succes against 6. gallegoes, of which he fired two: and notable victorie in his fight with foure gallyes, bound for Marceellus: to the eternall honour of our countrie, and no lesse worthy commendations of the valiant and braue minded gentleman and his followers, haning [sic] but one ship of burthen 240. tunnes, or thereabout, whereof himselfe is owner. Published for an encouragement to our English aduenturers, (gentlemen, sailars, and souldiars,) that serue against the euemies [sic] of God and our countrey.

div.head: Honourable actions of Edward Glemham, E≈øquire.
div.p:
ABout Augu≈øt la≈øt pa≈øt, 1590, that mo≈øt famous and venterous Gentleman, Edward Glemhall of Benhall in Suffolke, E≈øquire, ≈øet ≈øaile from Tilberry-hope neere Graue≈øend, onely accompanyed with one good ≈øhip, viz. The Edward & Con≈øtance, of the burthen of 240. Tunnes or vpward, and one Pinnis called the Fawlcon, which Ship and Pinnis he alone equiped, furni≈øhed and victualed, in ≈øuch ≈øort and with ≈øuch plentie, as ≈øildome hath there beene ≈øo much proui≈øion made for the like Voyage, all at his owne proper co≈øts. This famous Gentleman, being owner and ≈øole aduenturer: not onely ha≈ø≈øarded his goods to the fortune of the Seas, but ≈øcorning the Idle life which many de≈øireth, aduentured al≈øo his bodye in this voyage, ≈øhowing his worthie vndaunted minde, which holdeth honour in greater regarde, then ea≈øe at home, preferring countreys benefit, and his reputation farre beyond life, (albeit) his wor≈øhip in his Countrey, and liuings were ≈øuch, as might haue drawne the coward mindes of many, to haue liued among≈øt their freends, free from tho≈øe dangers imminent to trauailers, yea, ≈øuch were the bountifull ble≈ø≈øings of God, enduing him with tho≈øe worldly fauoures, as might haue woone him to haue left his determined voyage, hauing ≈øo aboundantly the loue generally of his neighbours, Gentlemen, and commons, among≈øt whom he kept good ho≈øpitality, fea≈øting his freends, and releeuing the poore plentifully, ≈øuch was the good minde both of the gentleman and his vertuous
wife, who≈øe wor≈øhipfull aunce≈øtrie, hath beene, and is, mo≈øt famous, both in Court and Countrie, being daughter and ≈øole heyre of a right wor≈øhipfull Knight, famous in his life, and of great po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions. But neither the de≈øire of liuing which he enioyed, the ≈øorrow of his right wor≈øhipfull Wife, nor the pitteous mone of his ≈øweet children, might remooue his ≈øetled determination from his intended voyage, which he vndertooke this la≈øt yeare, for the Ilands of the Suryes and Canaryes, whether at his departure hee framed his cour≈øe, giuing the like directions to his Pinnis, who he was enforced to leaue behinde him at Douer, to repaire ≈øome wants, but he neuer ≈øawe hir ≈øince, by the negligence of the Mai≈øter and Captaine which he left in her, to no little greefe of the Gentleman, & no ≈ømall di≈øcomfort to all his company.

All things furni≈øhed for his voiage, the great commander of the heauens and ≈øeas, fauouring his enterpri≈øe, he ≈øet ≈øaile from Douer roade, hauing the winde large at North Ea≈øt, which continued ≈øo eight daies, ≈øo that it freed him from our coa≈øt. Thus happily he recouered the Cape, and from thence to the Ilands, there ≈øpending his time, dooing ≈ømall good, vntill Nouember, abiding many ≈øharpe ≈øtormes of winde and weather, which they continued, when many were enfor≈øed to for≈øake the Ilandes, and returne home, keeping the Spani≈øh coa≈øt, without dooing any thing an≈øwerable to his valiant minde, loathing to returne without dooing ≈øome honourable exploite, a≈øwell for honour of his Countrey, as his reputation, his men, healthfull and in good liking, for whom was his cheefe≈øt care, for that he would profit them, who≈øe liuing is thereby maintained, their wiues and families, exteeming their good, more then his owne lo≈ø≈øe, which was likely to be of no ≈ømall importe.

Houering betweene the Ilandes, commaunded by the har≈øhnes of the windes, to ≈øeeke his be≈øt ≈øafetie, hauing little cha≈øe or none, and de≈øirous to releeue his companies with ≈øuch fre≈øh vittels as the Ilandes affords, he mo≈øt valiantlye accompted, to land on Saint Georges Iland. And hauing
coun≈øelled with his company thereof, they were all willing, as men that loue him, both for his valoure and courte≈øie, to follow him, in what ≈øeruice ≈øo euer, all condi≈øcending to hys will, he cau≈øeth ≈øpeedy preparation to be made for the ≈øame. And hauing a ≈ømall Caruill, which he had taken before at his ≈øtarne, for that ≈øhe drewe little water, was the fitter for the landing his companies: All things prouided, they attend but the tide for their be≈øt aduantage, and neere vpon a full ≈øea, he halled vp his long Boate and the Caruell, into which entered foure ≈øcore and ≈øixe men, 60 Shot, the re≈øt Pikes, blacke Billes, and other warlike abilliments, and in Gods name commit them≈øelues to their good fortunes.

The watch of the Iland, perceiuing theyr comming neere the ≈øhore, with their Ship, more then commonly any ≈øtranger dooth, had before giuen warnings, that the mo≈øt force of the Iland was there, ready to receaue them: which our men perceaued, yet could not be daunted with the ≈øight of them, but valiantly put forwards, attempting to land where they were mo≈øt ≈øharpely encountered by the enemie. But the Gunner taking aduantage, with a Sacare from the Ship, charged with a Chaine, made ≈øo good a ≈øhoote, that hee flew and di≈ømembred tenne or twelue, who ≈øeeing his ≈øucce≈ø≈øe aun≈øwerable to his de≈øire, hee playde ≈øtill vpon them with his Ordnance from the Shippe, which made them the ≈øooner to retire, ≈øo that the whole conflict at the fir≈øt landing, continued not pa≈øt two houres, when the Spaniards heartes began to quaile, and his men to bee of more courage, which the Spaniards perceauing, ≈øounded a retreate, and with all ≈øpeede, fled into the hie Countreyes, ≈øo thankes be to God, they ended onely with the lo≈ø≈øe of two men, be≈øides ≈øome hurt, yet did they great ≈øpoile among≈øt the Spaniards.

Being landed, and night at hande, they had no pollicie, to per≈øue them, wherefore marching into the lande a Mile or ≈øomething le≈ø≈øe, they encamped them≈øelues, di≈øpear≈øing ≈øundrye Sentenels, for watche, farre from the Campe,
diuers wayes, keeping a ≈øtrong watch in campe. That if the enimie ≈øhould haue come vpon them in the night, they might haue beene ready to receiue them.

But the Spaniards, hauing ≈øo bad a banquetiat their fir≈øt meetings, had no ha≈øt to come againe. Day being come, Generall Glemham commaunded certaine e≈øpials to be ≈øent out, to ≈øee if they could de≈øcrie the enemie, but they returned with little newes, ≈øauing they ≈øaw many armed in no araye, and diuers women and children, carrying goods to hide.

Vpon this newes, that worthy Gentleman, and braue Captaine, Mai≈øter Edward Horecourt his a≈ø≈øociate in tho≈øe his Voyages, willed the Generall to deuide the company, and he would lead the one of them: and ≈øo with En≈øignes di≈øplayed, to march in warlike order farther vp, to ≈øee what they would do: which coun≈øell the Generall accepted, and with ea≈øie paces marched on, largely di≈øtanted one from the other, to make them ≈øeeme farre more in number then they were, with Drums, Trumpets, and two En≈øignes di≈øplaid, yeeling ≈øuch terrible cryes as they marched, as might terrifie a great company.

The Generall gouerned by Captaine Horecourt, who≈øe experience in land ≈øeruice is much, hauing had charge of credit in the Low-countreys, Ireland, and Portingall, and therfore wholy directed by him, the two Companies marched in ≈øort like two wings, with intent and full re≈øolution, if there came ten men for one, to encounter them, and valiantly to die together, or gaine honour for euer with the enemie.

They had not marched halfe a league, when making a ≈øtand for ≈øome parley, the e≈øpyals brought word they ≈øawe one come, mounted as if he came to ≈øpeake with them, wherfore the Generall ≈øent a Guarde of Mu≈øketeares to meete him, and to ≈øtay him, if he had any thing to ≈øaye, for that hee ≈øhould not take view of their forces. When he came to this Courte of Guarde appointed to meete him: they demanded what he was? Who an≈øwered, he had to ≈øay to their Generall and Captaines, and de≈øired to be brought to their pre≈øence,
they ≈øtaide him there, and ≈øent worde to the Generall what hee was, who came accompanied with foure other Gentlemen, and his whole noi≈øe of Trumpets, mo≈øt brauely to ≈øpeake with him.
After entertainment giuen him in the be≈øt manner, for that he ≈øeemed ≈øome Cauelere, hee aduerti≈øed the Generall that he came from the Gouernour, to know what they were, and what they required.

The General v≈øing him kindely, gaue him milde ≈øpeeches, but willed him to returne his aun≈øwer thus. That he was a Gentleman of England, & what he pretended, he would not impart to any priuate man: but if the Gouernor would come him≈øelfe, he promi≈øed on the honour of an Engli≈øh Gentleman, he ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe and repa≈ø≈øe in ≈øafetie: if hee gaue not credit to his worde, ho≈øtage of reputation, Gentlemen of his countrie, no whit inferiour to the be≈øt Spaniard in the Ile, ≈øhould be deliuered for him.

With this an≈øwer, the Me≈ø≈øenger ha≈øtneth to the Gouernour: Who calling his Coun≈øell, required their opinions, who≈øe adui≈øes giuen, he came towards the Campe, accompanied with twelue others, well mounted, about ≈øome halfe mile from the Court of Guarde, they made ≈øtaye, and ≈øent vnto the Generall for his ho≈øtages, who ss he promi≈øed, ≈øent a Gentleman, that ≈øometimes attended the Earle of Warwike, Mai≈øter Hammon, one Mai≈øter Gore, and Mai≈øter Hunnings, Guarded with twentie Mu≈øketeares, who deliuered the Gentlemen, and receaued the Gouernour, conducting him to a place where the Generall made his ≈øtay, di≈øtant from his Campe.

Being mette, and hauing a while conferred, the General demanded to haue the Iland deliuered him, vnto the Queen of Englands v≈øe, which if they would, they ≈øhould haue libertie to depart with what they had there in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, if not, to commit it to the ha≈ø≈øard of the ≈øworde, for what aduantuge he had, he would keepe, or die for it: and what ≈øpoile he could make they ≈øhould be a≈ø≈øured of.

This demaund the Gouernour flatlye denyed, alledging he was a Gentleman, and ≈øworne to the King his Mai≈øter, as the Generall for the Queene of England, and that before his allegiance therein ≈øhould quaile, he would die with honour like a Gentleman. Yet quoth he, as ye are a Gentleman, and will fauour me heereafter, what there is in the Ile will do you plea≈øure, commaund it, condicionally that your companies ≈øpoyle not the Kings ≈øubiects, nor theyr goods, which rather then I may endure, I will hazzard all to my good Fortunes.

The Generall for that he vnder≈øtood not the Spani≈øh, was compelled to v≈øe an enterpretor, wherefore that hee might ≈øpeake his owne minde, he demaunded of the Gouernour if he ≈øpake Lattin, which he did excellent well, ≈øo in lattin, which the Generall ≈øpeakes as perfect as Engli≈øh, hee confermed what he had before ≈øpoken and no more.

The Generall craued ≈øome re≈øpect to an≈øwer him, leauing captaine Horecourt and the Mai≈øter which was newly come a≈øhore, to accompany him, he called the cheefe≈øt of all his company, aduerti≈øing what offers were made, and wild them to looke into the matter with adui≈øe, before they determined, for as he had brought them thether, he would in part be gouerned by theÃÑ, who aduentured as he did, though his charge was more, yet told them, that in his opinion, better ≈øome good end be made, then to aduenture farther, for that they were ≈øtrangers, not knowing theyr forces, neither the vantage or di≈øuantage of the place, and to what perrils they were ≈øubiect vnto, being of no more power, he referred to their directions to con≈øider. I ≈øpeake not this quoth the Generall of cowardis, for if I haue but twentie of you to ≈øtand by me, Saint George for all: I will end my life before I di≈øtaine the reputation of an Engli≈øh Gentleman.

The company hearing his re≈øolute minde, which they euer found, ≈øuch as he ≈øeemed, with a generall voice, put it to his di≈øcretion, vowing (what he did) to ratifie, either to peace, or fight it out, to take part with him ≈øo far as their liues would
go. The Generall gaue them thankes for their loues, & prote≈øted that he would want what≈øoeuer he had or ≈øhould haue in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, before they ≈øhould lacke. Thus greeued, to deliuer that aduantage which he had in his enemies country, he wi≈øhed but one hundred men more, to haue tryed h ‚Ä¢ s fortune with them, but he thought it ≈ømall pollicie, to refu≈øe tho≈øe offers, to ha≈ø≈øard their liues and all, con≈øidering his ≈ømall power, the enemie being in his owne countrey, likely to be releeued euery day with more ≈øupply, and they to haue nothing, but what by force they obtained, waying all things with equalitie as well his owne dangers as his companies, he returned the Gouernour this an≈øwer.

That con≈øidering he was a Gentleman, which helde his reputation in ≈øome accompt with his Mai≈øter the King, and that it might greatly blemi≈øh his credit, if they ≈øhould bid theÃÑ battell and ouerthrow them, of which by Gods helpe he was a≈ø≈øured, he had with earne≈øt reque≈øt per≈øwaded the company to giue ouer their aduantage, on tho≈øe conditions pre≈øently to be performed, viz. That they ≈øhould haue of victuals of al ≈øorts the Iland affordeth, ≈øufficient for the vitteling the ≈øhip, and 1000 Crownes among≈øt them, to be deuided in recompence of the lo≈ø≈øe of their men ≈ølaine at their landing.

To tho≈øe conditions the Gouernour condi≈øcended, and on his credit to deliuer it in one daies re≈øpect this matter ended. The Generall enuited the Gouernor to ≈øuch viands as they had, and ≈øo ≈øpent the time a while with freend≈øhip, carrew≈øing to the health of the Engli≈øh Queene, and making good cheere, when night approaching, the Gouernour tooke leaue to depart, earne≈øtly entreating the Generall, and Captaine Horecourt, to accompanie him to his hou≈øe, where to ≈øuch entertainment as the Iland affordes, they ≈øhould be welcome, and ≈øo a≈ø≈øured from any euill to be offered to him, or his company, as if he were in his be≈øt freends hou≈øe in England. But the Generall knowing what it is to tru≈øt a recon≈øiled foe, gaue him as hartie thanks as his offers were kinde, yet would tru≈øt him but as a Spaniard, ≈øo he departed, and
the Gentlemen returned which was deliuered for him, vnto whom the Spaniards had giuen many gifts.

The Gouernor being departed, order was taken for the watche, which was ≈øet in diuers places, for feare of treacherie in the night. About two houres in the night, a Trumpet ≈øounded a parley neere the Campe, which ≈øo amazed them, that they were greatly in doubt of the Spaniards trecherie, and betooke them all to armes pre≈øently. The Generall, according to law of armes, ≈øummoned him againe with one other Trumpet, then after with his whole noi≈øe, and ≈øent Captaine Horecourt with a guarde of Mu≈øketteares, to heare the cau≈øe of his comming, who found none but three men ≈øent from the Gouernour, with ≈øuch vyands dre≈ø≈øed as was puruayed for his owne ≈øupper, and one But of Canary Wine, which the Generall thankefully accepted, and rewarding the trumpet largely with Crownes, ≈øent him away.

The next daye about two of the clocke after noone, the Gouernour came againe to the Generall, accompanied with a troope of Gentlemen, where they pa≈ø≈øed the time in banqueting, attending the coÃÑming of the cariages which brought the victuals, viz. Beefe, Kids, 30 Buts of Sack & Canary wines, Ru≈øke, Meale, Flower, Salt, pumpions, & other proui≈øion, ≈øufficient for nine moneths victuals. The Spaniard hauing kept his word, the Generall was loath his curte≈øies ≈øhould go altogether vnrequited, wherefore he enuited the Gouernour & his company to dinner aborde his ≈øhip the next day, which the re≈øt were loth to coÃÑ≈øent vnto, which the generall perceauing, told them flatly & halfe in choller, that they did di≈øtru≈øt him, but (quoth he) you ≈øhal not need, for the wor≈øt Engli≈øhman doth hold his word of honor in as much regard as their king, & that if his boy for him had promi≈øed any thing he would maintaine it as his life. But Gentlemen (quoth he) ≈øeeing you ≈øu≈øpect my word, & that ye may accept my offer without di≈øtru≈øt, for that I would willingly haue your company, my warrant ≈øhall be tho≈øe pledges which I will not leaue for the kingdome of Spaine.

The gouernor being of milde nature, was ≈øorry to ≈øee him ≈øo di≈øquiet: wherefore with gentle words, he fir≈øt pacified the Generall, then entreated his freends to accompany him, which they ea≈øily graunted, and accordingly came the next day, where the Generall fea≈øted them in braue maner, to the honour of his countrey, & his owne worthy commendations.

The day folowing, he that ordained wind & tide to ≈øerue the purpo≈øes of men, ≈øent theÃÑ a faire & plea≈øing gale, which cau≈øed him the rather to ≈øet ≈øaile froÃÑ thence, & ≈øo ranged along≈øt the Ilands againe, ≈øeeking his good fortune. The 5 day after he put from S. Georges, he di≈øcried two tall ≈øhips, to whoÃÑ he gaue cha≈øe, with a ≈øcant gale, all night, vntill the next day at noone, when bearing with theÃÑ, the generall hailed them, & coÃÑ manded theÃÑ to ≈øtrike for the Queene of England.
